Description: Fragment of marble moulding with a herculean knot. The two adjoining fragments show two smooth ropes of differing thickness (2.00 – 2.3 cm) that are entwined to a herculean knot on the rim of a presumably deep bowl. An even surface is preserved on the narrow edge of the fragment which could possibly have been the upper or under layer of the relief or vertical adjoining area. The light grey marble is broken off on all sides.
Findspot: Excavated/Findspot: Sanctuary of Apollo (Naukratis) (Attributed by Petrie to the 'second temple of Apollo'.)
Curator's comments: The even surface on the narrow edge could indicate the relief had originally more layers. The context of the fragment is not known. Furthermore no dating features are preserved. Published (Koenigs 2007, 343 Cat. 40; Petrie 1886, 14f. Pl. 14; Prinz 1908, 10; Bissing 1951, 72)
Bibliographic references: Sculpture / Catalogue of Greek Sculpture in the British Museum (B408)
Petrie 1886 / Naukratis. Part I., 1884-85 (p. 14, pl. XIV A, bottom right)
Koenigs 2007 / Archaische griechische Bauteile (Cat. no.40, p.343, pl. 27)
Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (AA.48) (Phase 3)
